title: ShaunInman website redesign
content:
[http://www.shauninman.com/post/heap/2006/10/16/the\_9th\_incarnation\_of\_shauninman\_com](http://web.archive.org/web/20061120151316/http:/www.shauninman.com/post/heap/2006/10/16/the_9th_incarnation_of_shauninman_com)

Just saw the new shauninman redesign. Love the new typography based layout!
author: j_polo9

comments.content: I do like the simplicity. But the small nav text is nearly unreadable on my end. And the type becoming [unreadable over time](http://web.archive.org/web/20061120151316/http:/www.shauninman.com/post/about/the_heap/) is an interesting concept, but not very practical.
Clean and simple, but he must not want his site read.

I think it’s a little dull and the font size is way too big - who has the patience to scroll down like that. I’m not getting the concept - visually - of the type getting lighter over time either. I’d click on this once and not go back.
Stephen Coles: I agree with you regarding the minimalistic approach. It’s conceptually brilliant. Then again, I reckon he isn’t leaning towards the practical approach at the moment.

<cite>Helvetica Neue (or Arial Eue on typographically challenged OSes).</cite>

I like that. Even though it’s based on a mispronunciation.
i guess aesthetically if i just went to the site randomely I would not like it. But I love the fact that he is willing to throw out new ideas and explore beyond the normal.

I’ve gone back and read, not scanned, the new site with the two readme pages dedicated to the new design. While I still think the contrast is too low and it does making reading not-so-fun (for me anyway), the concept is mind-blowing and very, very cool.

I actually do like the size of the type as I’m sick-to-death of type so small it hurts to focus. (ergo: I’m loving the trend for large type.) Until the WC3 can find a way to embed fonts without violating the EULA, I won’t complain about Helvetica or Arial or Georgia or (insert), because they could be using something worse. His attention to line-length and line-spacing is good, I think. Scrolling comes with the territory. I’d rather scroll than click to get the next page.

He mentions that he’s still working on the alogrithms for the color, so I hope the contrast is increased (at least a little more).
